user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of parse_http_version:
```c
static bool
parse_http_version (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                    const char *http_string,
                    size_t len)
{
  const char *const h = http_string; /**< short alias */
  mhd_assert (NULL != http_string);

  /* String must start with 'HTTP/d.d', case-sensetive match.
   * See https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9112#name-http-version */
  if ((HTTP_VER_LEN != len) ||
      ('H' != h[0]) || ('T' != h[1]) || ('T' != h[2]) || ('P' != h[3]) ||
      ('/' != h[4])
      || ('.' != h[6]) ||
      (('0' > h[5]) || ('9' < h[5])) ||
      (('0' > h[7]) || ('9' < h[7])))
  {
    connection->rq.http_ver = MHD_HTTP_VER_INVALID;
    transmit_error_response_static (connection,
                                    MHD_HTTP_BAD_REQUEST,
                                    REQUEST_MALFORMED);
    return false;
  }
  if (1 == h[5] - '0')
  {
    /* HTTP/1.x */
    if (1 == h[7] - '0')
      connection->rq.http_ver = MHD_HTTP_VER_1_1;
    else if (0 == h[7] - '0')
      connection->rq.http_ver = MHD_HTTP_VER_1_0;
    else
      connection->rq.http_ver = MHD_HTTP_VER_1_2__1_9;

    return true;
  }

  if (0 == h[5] - '0')
  {
    /* Too old major version */
    connection->rq.http_ver = MHD_HTTP_VER_TOO_OLD;
    transmit_error_response_static (connection,
                                    MHD_HTTP_HTTP_VERSION_NOT_SUPPORTED,
                                    REQ_HTTP_VER_IS_TOO_OLD);
    return false;
  }

  connection->rq.http_ver = MHD_HTTP_VER_FUTURE;
  transmit_error_response_static (connection,
                                  MHD_HTTP_HTTP_VERSION_NOT_SUPPORTED,
                                  REQ_HTTP_VER_IS_NOT_SUPPORTED);
  return false;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No function parameter is assigned to or otherwise modified in this function. Details:
- The pointer parameter 'connection' is used only to modify the object it points to (connection->rq.http_ver) and to pass the pointer to other functions. Modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter is permitted by Rule 17.8; the pointer itself is not reassigned anywhere in the function.
- The pointer parameter 'http_string' is aliased to a local const pointer (const char *const h = http_string). Neither 'http_string' nor the local alias 'h' is modified, and no write-through to the pointed-to characters occurs (they are treated as const).
- The non-pointer parameter 'len' is only read (compared) and never assigned to.
- There are no statements such as connection = ..., http_string = ..., len = ..., or pointer increments/decrements that would modify parameter variables.
Therefore there are no code fragments in this function that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 and nothing needs to be investigated further with respect to that rule.
